projectDesc.p: "水調歌頭" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “Water Melody”
Since when has the bright moon been there?
I raise my wine-cup and ask the azure sky.
I wonder, in the heavenly palace,
which year is it tonight?
I want to ride the wind and return,
but I fear that in the jade buildings,
so lofty and high, one cannot stand the coldness.
I stand up and dance with the pure shadow;
isn’t it better to be in the world of men?
It turns at the vermillion tower,
hangs down at the painted door,
and shines this sleepless one.
I should not resent,
but why does it always wax when we are apart?
Men grieve, rejoice, separate, and reunite;
the moon turns dim or clear, wax or wane.
Since antiquity, such things can hardly be perfect.
We can only hope that we can live long lives,
looking at the moon together, across a thousand miles.
